It breaks the problem into the exact same two‑step routine we practiced earlier, but with only **four** candidate lines (so it’s a little easier). ### 📋 Problem recap A regular **square** has a small **equilateral triangle** glued to the **mid‑point of the bottom side** of the square. The triangle points straight **downward**, outside the square. ### **Step 1 – List the candidate symmetry lines** | Shape | Candidate lines (just name them) | |-------|----------------------------------| | Square | 1) Vertical line through the centre
2) Horizontal line through the centre
3) Diagonal from top‑left to bottom‑right
4) Diagonal from top‑right to bottom‑left | | Triangle (isolated) | 1) Line that bisects its base (the line that goes straight up through the midpoint of the base) | *(You already have this list – you can just copy it into the table if you like.)* ### **Step 2 – Test each square line** For each of the four square lines, ask: > *If I fold the whole figure (square + triangle) along this line, does the triangle land on top of itself?* Fill in the table below with **Yes** or **No** and a one‑sentence reason. | Square line (your numbering) | Does the triangle map onto itself? | Reason (one sentence) | |------------------------------|------------------------------------|-----------------------| | 1) Vertical line through centre | | | | 2) Horizontal line through centre | | | | 3) Diagonal TL‑BR | | | | 4) Diagonal TR‑BL | | | ### **Step 3 – Count the survivors** - Count how many “Yes” answers you have. - That count is the **number of lines of symmetry** for the combined shape. - (Optional) List the surviving line(s). --- ## 🎯 What to do now 1. **Copy the table** above into your reply. 2. **Fill in “Yes/No”** for each line and give the short reason. 3. **Tell me the total** number of symmetry lines you obtain. You’ve already mastered the first part (listing the candidates), so the next step is just a quick “test‑and‑tick” for each line. Give it a try—you’ll see the answer emerge naturally! --- ### If you get stuck - Remember: the triangle is attached at the **mid‑point of the bottom side** of the square. -
